awd_titl_txt: CPS: Frontier: Collaborative Research: VeHICaL: Verified Human Interfaces, Control, and Learning for Semi-Autonomous Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Frontier project "Verified Human Interfaces, Control, and Learning for Semi-Autonomous Systems (VeHICaL)" is developing the foundations of verified co-design of interfaces and control for human cyber-physical systems (h-CPS) --- cyber-physical systems that operate in concert with human operators. VeHICaL aims to bring a formal approach to designing both interfaces and control for h-CPS, with provable guarantees.

The VeHICaL project is grounded in a novel problem formulation that elucidates the unique requirements on h-CPS including not only traditional correctness properties on autonomous controllers but also quantitative requirements on the logic governing switching or sharing of control between human operator and autonomous controller, the user interface, privacy properties, etc. The project is making contributions along four thrusts: (1) formalisms for modeling h-CPS; (2) computational techniques for learning, verification, and control of h-CPS; (3) design and validation of sensor and human-machine interfaces, and (4) empirical evaluation in the domain of semi-autonomous vehicles. The VeHICaL approach is bringing a conceptual shift of focus away from separately addressing the design of control systems and human-machine interaction and towards the joint co-design of human interfaces and control using common modeling formalisms and requirements on the entire system.  This co-design approach is making novel intellectual contributions to the areas of formal methods, control theory, sensing and perception, cognitive science, and human-machine interfaces. 

Cyber-physical systems deployed in societal-scale applications almost always interact with humans. The foundational work being pursued in the VeHICaL project is being validated in two application domains: semi-autonomous ground vehicles that interact with human drivers, and semi-autonomous aerial vehicles (drones) that interact with human operators. A principled approach to h-CPS design --- one that obtains provable guarantees on system behavior with humans in the loop --- can have an enormous positive impact on the emerging national ``smart'' infrastructure. In addition, this project is pursuing a substantial educational and outreach program including: (i) integrating research into undergraduate and graduate coursework, especially capstone projects; (ii) extensive online course content leveraging existing work by the PIs; (iii) a strong undergraduate research program, and (iv) outreach and summer programs for school children with a focus on reaching under-represented groups.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CPS Frontier project, VeHICaL, has contributed towards developing the foundations of verified co-design of interfaces and control for human cyber-physical systems (h-CPS) --- cyber-physical systems that operate in concert with human operators. With increasing automation in societal systems and its impact on the future of work, h-CPS, also known as human-robot systems, are of growing importance. The VeHICaL project addressed the design of h-CPS so as to enable safe and seamless interaction between humans and robots, and brought a formal approach to designing both interfaces and control for h-CPS, with verifiable guarantees.

 

The project resulted in the following major accomplishments:

 

(i) Intellectual Merit: The project has made major technical contributions along three technical thrusts, including formal modeling of h-CPS, integrating control, verification, and learning for h-CPS design, and design of novel perception components and human-machine interfaces.  Some research highlights that have had significant impact and are highly-cited include the paradigms of interaction-aware control and resource-rational planning; seminal work on learning formal specifications from demonstrations; the FasTrak approach for navigation through unknown, cluttered environments; a Hamilton-Jacobi reachability-based framework for predicting and analyzing human motion for safe planning; the Scenic probabilistic programming language for modeling AI-enabled h-CPS; algorithms for the design, verification, testing, and run-time assurance of AI-enabled h-CPS, implemented in the VerifAI open-source tool; a framework for assume-guarantee contracts and verified protocols for safety and progress for autonomous vehicles; the HindSight system for situational awareness for bicyclists; novel perception systems for robot gaze based feedback to humans and for vibro-acoustical interactions for vehicle occupants; the Perception Handoff problem and associated formal model and analysis; and frameworks and datasets for formal usability evaluation of driver assistance systems and privacy-preserving drowsiness detection. Technologies developed in the project were demonstrated on unmanned aerial vehicle testbeds, ground vehicle testing grounds, and industrial driving simulators at UC Berkeley and in collaboration with industrial partners. Datasets and benchmarks developed in the VeHICaL project are available publicly, and several have had significant impact in guiding the research in h-CPS and human-robot interaction.

 

(ii) Broader Impacts: Results from the proposed work have had significant impacts on teaching, on industrial practice, and on the mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The open-source Scenic and VerifAI toolkits have been successfully demonstrated on industrial case studies in the self-driving and avionics domains, and state of the art industrial autonomous driving simulators have integrated the Scenic language into their offerings. Several successful industry workshops were conducted, both in person and virtually during the COVID-19 pandemic. VeHICaL PIs provided advice on autonomous vehicle safety to government agencies, the World Economic Forum Safe Drive Initiative, and to companies working on autonomous vehicle technology. Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers supported by the project have obtained positions in academia and industry; in particular, over ten VeHICaL project alumni are now faculty at leading universities in the US and around the world, and have launched their own research programs based on research started in the VeHICaL project. The VeHICaL project contributed personnel, modules, and financial support to outreach programs for school children and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, including notably the Girls in Engineering program at UC Berkeley. Technology developed in the project has been used in class projects, has incorporated contributions by several undergraduate researchers, and contributed towards the development of new courses and course material.
